comment.narrative: Due to containment measures to prevent Covid-19 there was restricted movements as well as curfews forcing young people to stay away. Most young people, however, visited the resource centers in the evenings to access commodities such as condoms and counselling services.

comment.narrative: Due to budget constraints and the fact that the project was moving towards the final year, formation of new networks was not envisioned. Instead, the existing networks were engaged and strengthened eg the community advisory teams were linked to the government led Area advisory councils.

title.narrative: Goal 3. Adolescent girls and boys take informed action on their sexual health
% boys between 15 and 24 that have ever utilized SRHR services including modern contraceptives

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in two intervention areas (Ilodokilani&Ewanso Kedong). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1400 using a standard formula- taking into account possible ?design effects? because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1728 questionnaires were administered- which was above to the planned target. No contributing partners.

title.narrative: Goal 3. Adolescent girls and boys take informed action on their sexual health
% Boys between 15 and 24 that have ever utilized SRHR services- including modern contraceptives
Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services- and child protection services
% of not currently married boys and men (aged 15-24 years) who prefer a non-circumsized female as future partner
Goal 3. Adolescent girls and boys take informed action on their sexual health
Goal 3. Adolescent girls and boys take informed action on their sexual health

title.narrative: Men and boys are successfully and actively engaged to reduce CM- TP and FGM and C
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C and CM and TP (disaggregated by CM FGM and C and TP)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C CM and TP is considered low by men and boys themselves.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The qualitative interviews at endline reported minimal active engagement of men and boys in strategies for reducing TP CM and FGM/C. Male participants often highlighted what should be done as opposed to what they were actively engaged in to reduce these harmful practices.

title.narrative: Goal 5. Policy makers and duty bearers commit to implement laws and policies on CM and FGM and C
# of new or adjusted national and local law (incl. by-laws) and policies prohibiting CM and FGM and C (disaggregated by CM and FGM and C and by policies laws national level local level)

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Many bylaws exists but are insufficiently reinforced by community leaders and other gatekeepers

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of CM and TP

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Many gatekeepers have knowledge about the harms of child marriage and teenage pregnancies.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The endline participants reported that through the efforts of various stakeholders there has been an increased awareness on the dangers of child marriage and teenage pregnancy generally. During discussions with parents it was reported that the YES I DO programme has contributed to creating awareness of the negative consequences of child marriage and teenage pregnancy. Reference was also made to girls experiencing difficulties /complications of childbirth and a general hardship environment. The role of the chief has been heralded in supporting and reinforcing adherence to the information provided by other stakeholders working in the community.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of FGM and C

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of FGM and C.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Most gatekeepers are knowledgeable about the harms of FGM and C but some gatekeepers see mainly the advantages of FGM.
Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Gatekeepers are aware of the harmful effects of FGM/C.

title.narrative: Adolescent girls and boys have increased access to ASRHR information and services and child protection services
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in current access to SRHR information by girls and boys aged 15 to 24 years

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years. And focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Some girls and boys access SRHR information from peers parents teachers or health workers.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Young girls reported to receive SRHR information. It was also reported that girls are expected to mostly get information from their mothers while boys are expected to get information largely from their fathers. While some young participants were emphatic to state that they were being provided with reproductive health information by teachers in school (including taking exams on SRH topics) and at home others spoke of not receiving enough sexual education. Most of us are not getting sexual education (FGD 15-19).

title.narrative: Goal 1. Community members and gate-keepers have changed attitudes and take action to prevent CM FGM and C and TP.
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent FGM and C (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. FGM.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all Some gatekeepers are actively involved in preventing FGM but some also encourage FGM and consequently TP and CM.

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all FGM/C practice is still in place. However there are reported gradual changes in the practice of FGM/C. The data suggest that FGM/C is now practiced largely in secret largely because of enhanced knowledge among community members that the practice is illegal - a positive development in itself. It was reported that because of the high awareness of the anti-FGM/C law people often tended to conduct FGM alongside male circumcision as a camouflage. This is a departure from the flamboyance that accompanied the traditional ceremonies around FGM/C in the past.

title.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. CM and TP.

comment.narrative: Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all me gatekeepers are actively involved in preventing FGM TP and CM but many also encourage and are in favour of FGM and consequently TP and CM .

Scale: 0=no 1=few 2=some 3=most 4=all The endline participants agreed that there are some changes. Some parents are beginning to embrace formal education for both boys and girls as a protective measure against teenage pregnancy. Parents acknowledged the role they need to play in supporting girls and protecting them from teenage pregnancy. Through gatekeepers there has been awareness creation on the dangers of child marriage which seems to have informed a repulsive attitude towards CM and TP. In one focus group discussion with young men the role of the chief was heralded in supporting and reinforcing adherence to the information provided by other stakeholders working in the community.

title.narrative: Goal 5. Policy makers and duty bearers commit to implement laws and policies on CM and FGM and C
# of new or adjusted national and local law (incl. by-laws) and policies prohibiting CM and FGM and C (disaggregated by CM and FGM and C and by policies laws national level local level)

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: No difference at baseline and midline. Knowledge on by-laws were not expressed during the interviews on FGM/C, CM, TP and no new or adjusted national and local laws have been spoken about.

title.narrative: Political awareness increased and political will created
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in policy makers actively and openly supporting gender equality and girls rights

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

title.narrative: Men and boys are successfully and actively engaged to reduce CM- TP and FGM and C
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C and CM and TP (disaggregated by CM FGM and C and TP)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: Some respondents expressed that in general boys have hardly a voice; it is mainly older men who have a say. AMREF has worked with boys, but the applied method was not actively engaging boys. Some young male respondents felt they were not listened too, it was more like a one-way information provision. Videos were shown to the girls and the mothers after the video the girls were fearful of the images. This approach was not applied with the boys, although they seem to feel it would have also been useful for them too. The video showed the different types of FGM/C.

title.narrative: Goal 2. Adolescent girls and boys are meaningfully engaged to claim their SRH rights
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls and boys between 15 and 24 years old who feel they can advocate for themselves

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years. And focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years

comment.narrative: Most girls and boys admit that they have very little space to advocate for their issues, especially issues that go against the culture or are sensitive. Within the household boys are capable to talk directly with their father but girls mainly have to communicate via their mother with the father who is the main decision maker in the household. Boys and girls feel more safe to discuss sensitive issues with their teachers or at church fora. young people are not very much organised to join forces to advocate for their issues. However girls or boys with higher education are more respected and can provide a bit more input.

title.narrative: Goal 1. Community members and gate-keepers have changed attitudes and take action to prevent CM FGM and C and TP.
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent FGM and C (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. FGM.

comment.narrative: Teachers, education officers and chiefs are most vocal in speaking out against FGM/C. Parents are more silent about FGM/C, because many are still in favour of this practice, to fit into society and to get girls married, especially households with less to non-educated parents. Not many parents take an active stand against FGM/C. Although the influence of Education and Christianity bring some shifts, culture and tradition have a much bigger influence in these communities.

title.narrative: Increased access to safe post-primary education for adolescent girls and child protection school systems in place
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of CM and TP

comment.narrative: As well as during baseline gatekeepers are aware of the harms of child marriage and teenage pregnancies. Like consequences for the body, consequences of teenage pregancy > child marriage. Some girls realised that their freedom will be reduced in marriage through their husband or that they can even be beaten up. Most respndents do not see any advantage of child marriage, except for the bride price within the family, and that households will have more children when you start early.

title.narrative: Community and gate keepers understand benefits of changing norms and are aware of alternatives in relation to CM and TP and FGM
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of FGM and C

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of FGM and C.

comment.narrative: Overall most gatekeepers are very well informed about consequences and laws against FGM/C. Still some community members are not convinced about the health consequences of FGM/C because especially (young) men have not seen the direct consequences. Their knowledge is based on hearsays in the community. Video's are an effective mean but should not only show the circumcision itself but also the effects of FGM/C like bleeding, infections, fistula or difficulties in delivery -in the local language-.
